name: Ayurveda
summary: A comprehensive traditional medical system from India emphasizing individualized lifestyle, diet, herbal formulas, bodywork, and detoxification to restore balance among the doshas (Vata, Pitta, Kapha).
description: Ayurveda is a traditional South Asian medical system with roots >2,000 years old. It aims to optimize health by assessing constitutional type (prakriti) and imbalances (vikriti) across three doshas—Vata, Pitta, Kapha. Treatments blend lifestyle and diet, botanical medicines (single herbs and multi-herb formulations), body-based therapies (abhyanga massage, shirodhara), yoga and breathwork, and cleansing procedures (Panchakarma). Modern research suggests potential benefits for osteoarthritis, metabolic risk factors, stress, and some functional disorders, while evidence quality varies. Safety depends on qualified guidance, product quality, and appropriate integration with conventional care.

delivery_methods: Dispensed herbal preparations and medicated oils
Supervised Panchakarma in residential or clinic settings
metadata.invasiveness_level: Non-invasive to minimally invasive (some nasal/rectal therapies within Panchakarma)
metadata.session_duration: 60–90 minutes for initial consult; 30–60 minutes follow-ups; bodywork 45–90 minutes
metadata.training_required: Licensed/registered Ayurvedic practitioner where regulated; otherwise training via accredited Ayurveda schools; integrative physicians with additional Ayurveda training.
metadata.regulatory_status: Varies by country; in some regions regulated as traditional medicine. Product quality standards differ; some imported products lack rigorous testing.

primary_indications: Stress, anxiety, and sleep disturbance (with yoga/pranayama)
contraindications: Absolute: Unsupervised Panchakarma in medically unstable patients; known allergy to ingredients.

Relative: Pregnancy/lactation (many herbs contraindicated), liver or kidney disease, anticoagulation/antiplatelet therapy, planned surgery (herb–drug interactions), uncontrolled chronic conditions requiring conventional stabilization.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Lifestyle and gentle bodywork are generally safe. Risks include herb–drug interactions, contamination/adulteration (e.g., heavy metals in some preparations), hepatotoxicity from certain botanicals, dehydration/electrolyte issues with laxative or emetic procedures, and infections if hygiene is poor.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Variable: moderate for knee osteoarthritis (some herbal formulas/oils); low-to-moderate for metabolic risk modification and functional GI; limited or mixed for many other indications.

sections.text: Ayurveda targets whole-person regulation through diet, circadian routines, sleep optimization, herbs, and bodywork to restore dosha balance. Biomedically, specific botanicals show anti-inflammatory, antioxidative, and adaptogenic effects (e.g., curcuminoids, withanolides, guggulsterones). Oil-based massage and heat/steam may reduce nociceptive signaling and muscle tone, while yoga/pranayama modulate autonomic balance and stress pathways.

sections.preparation: Constitution and imbalance assessment; review of medical history and medications; shared goal-setting; informed consent about benefits/risks and product quality.
procedure: Diet and lifestyle plan (meal timing, food choices matched to constitution, sleep and daily routines).
Prescription of herbals/topicals (e.g., Triphalā for bowel regulation, turmeric-based formulas for inflammation, ashwagandha for stress/sleep when appropriate).
Bodywork (e.g., abhyanga oil massage, localized oil treatments; shirodhara in select cases).
Consider Panchakarma only with medical screening and trained supervision.
sections.frequency: Follow-ups every 2–4 weeks initially; bodywork 1–2×/week during active phase.
sections.duration: Initial course 6–12 weeks; longer for chronic conditions.
sections.total_treatment_time: Highly individualized; reassess outcomes every 4–8 weeks.

items: Diet-first, herb-light protocols for conservative care

immediate: Relaxation, improved digestion comfort after diet changes/bodywork
short_term: Reduction in pain/stiffness, better sleep and energy, improved bowel regularity
long_term: Sustained symptom control with lifestyle adherence; possible reductions in pain medication needs; improved stress resilience

uncommon: Headache or dizziness with steam/heat therapies
rare: Hepatotoxicity or nephrotoxicity from certain botanicals or contaminated products
Heavy metal exposure from poorly manufactured remedies

absolute: Unsupervised aggressive detox (emesis/purgation) in medically fragile patients
relative: Pregnancy/lactation (avoid many herbs such as ashwagandha, guggul; use diet/lifestyle only)
Liver or kidney disease (avoid hepatotoxic/nephrotoxic botanicals; require monitoring)
Autoimmune/thyroid disorders (certain herbs may alter immune or thyroid activity)
special_considerations: Source herbs from reputable suppliers with third-party testing (heavy metals, pesticides, adulterants).
Coordinate with medical team; review medications to avoid interactions (e.g., with anticoagulants, antidiabetics, sedatives, thyroid meds).
Hydration and gentle pacing for any cleansing procedures.

ideal_candidates: Individuals seeking lifestyle-based, holistic adjuncts for chronic conditions
Patients with osteoarthritis or stress-related symptoms wanting nonpharmacologic options
Motivated patients who can implement diet and routine changes
screening_required: Medication and supplement review for interactions
Liver/kidney function if planning prolonged herb use

lifestyle_recommendations: Balanced, minimally processed diet matched to symptoms

sections.total_treatment_cost: Herbs/topicals vary ($20–$150+/month). Panchakarma programs can range from $2,000–$8,000+ depending on duration and setting.
sections.insurance_coverage: Variable/limited; some services (e.g., integrative visits) may be covered; products typically out-of-pocket.

items: Prioritize lifestyle and well-sourced, standardized botanicals; avoid polyherbal stacking without rationale.
Track outcomes (pain scales, sleep, GI symptoms, weight/waist, labs when relevant).
Educate on product quality and heavy-metal risk; prefer GMP and third-party tested brands.
Introduce one change at a time to isolate benefits and side effects.
